thread.title: CSX on Faster Track; Oil’s Shipping Backup; Streamlining Retail Suppliers

author: Paul Page
title: CSX on Faster Track; Oil’s Shipping Backup; Streamlining Retail Suppliers
text:
0 COMMENTS Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox .
CSX Corp. CSX 7.85% is getting more profitable as it gets smaller. The freight railroad more than doubled its net profit in the first quarter to $695 million and showed big gains in service performance, only a few months after Chief Executive James Foote undertook an “apology tour” to sell CSX’s shipping customers on the turnaround efforts . The WSJ’s Justin Lahart writes the results signal that CSX has its operations in order following snafus that came as the carrier implemented a plan by the late chief executive Hunter Harrison. CSX’s revenue inched up only slightly from a year ago in the first quarter as volumes declined. But the company slashed its operating ratio to 63.7% from 73.2%, and critical service measures for train velocity and dwell time showed big improvements. For now, at least, running fewer trains means smoother operations and bigger profits.
Oil is backing up so much in the Permian basin that producers may have to look to trucks to get more of the crude moving. The West Texas and New Mexico region at the heart of the U.S. shale boom has become a top area globally for expanding oil production. The WSJ’s Alison Sider and Bradley Olson report it now appears to be choking on its own growth . Permian producers are encountering congested pipelines and shortages of materials and workers, souring some energy executives on forecasts that production will climb by a third within two years. The bottlenecks highlight how investment in the oil fields has outpaced infrastructure development and overwhelmed pipelines. That’s threatening to hit financial returns as producers struggle to bring more equipment and workers into the region and even look to ship crude over the road.
Fashion retailer Primark is using a streamlined purchasing system with suppliers to help improve its profit margins. The U.K. chain has undertaken the shift in sourcing as it continues “refining its model” for expansion in the U.S., Chief Financial Officer John Bason tells the WSJ’s Nina Trentmann, part of a measured approach to growth in a tumultuous market for brick-and-mortar retailers. Mr. Bason says the company is “becoming more professional” in its purchasing strategy, and is focusing more on big suppliers to take advantage of economies of scale in its sourcing. The company even sources certain items from only one supplier, reducing the cost per item sold. The subsidiary of Associated British Food PLC is trying to halt a slide in profit margin that’s taken the critical financial measure from 14.1% in 2006 to 9.8% in the six months ending March 3.
ECONOMY & TRADE Photo: Bloomberg News President Donald Trump’s proposed tariffs on China stand to create winners and losers among U.S. manufacturers. The tariffs will have a disproportionate impact on factories that rely more on certain Chinese imports, the WSJ’s Andrew Tangel and Theo Francis write, potentially driving up costs that would put them at a competitive disadvantage . An analysis of data from research firm Panjiva shows China is a major source of overall imports for only a minority of the products on Mr. Trump’s tariffs list. Companies that buy those components are likely to bear the brunt of the tariffs. Trade figures show the same tariff also could hit two companies in the same industry differently, depending on where they source their components. Many will be seeking exemptions to the tariffs to keep their trans-Pacific shipments coming and their costs in check.
QUOTABLE
‘ No apology tour anymore. That’s canceled, nothing to apologize for. The railroad is running great. ’
—James Foote, CSX chief executive, on an earnings call on the railroad’s first-quarter report.
Number of the Day 12 The number of container ships sent for scrapping so far in 2018, down from 70 in the same period a year ago, according to Alphaliner .
IN OTHER NEWS The Federal Reserve found economic activity expanding across the U.S. in recent weeks, with wages growing only modestly . (WSJ)
The engine failure on a Southwest Airlines Co. flight puts a spotlight on one of commercial aviation’s most commonly used engines . (WSJ)
Rivals Amazon.com Inc. and Best Buy Co. are joining forces to sell television sets powered by Amazon’s Fire TV operating system. (WSJ)
Bon-Ton Stores Inc. will start closing its remaining stores and go out of business after a bankruptcy judge said she would approved the sale of the retailer’s assets. (WSJ)
Chinese exporters at a major trade fair say a rising yuan is a bigger concern than prospects for a trade war with the U.S. (South China Morning Post)
The European Union is fast-tracking trade talks with Japan and Singapore to fight what it calls U.S. protectionism. (Agence France-Presse)
Gatemore Capital Management has built a significant stake in Wincanton and wants the British logistics company to sell one of its two divisions . (Logistics Manager)
Rusal has stopped placing orders with logistics firms that ship its exports since the Russian aluminum giant was hit by U.S. sanctions . (Maritime Professional)
Pacific International Lines swung to an $85 million profit in 2017 on strong gains in container shipping and its Singamas container manufacturing holding. (Shipping Watch)
Egypt will run its ports 24 hours a day after complaints of “long waiting times” and shipper storage fees . (Reuters)
British retailer Marks & Spencer is consolidating its network of distribution centers as part of an effort to run a more nimble supply chain . (Post & Parcel)
Flatbed operator Daseke Inc. bought Aveda Transportation and Energy Services , a Canadian oil-rig moving company . (Commercial Carrier Journal)
Siemens AG acquired Agilion GmbH, a German supplier of tracking systems for industrial operations. (DC Velocity)
The European Union set a non-binding target to cut food waste in supply chains by 50% by 2030. (FruitNet)
